questions.text: What is the dose range of lithium in mEq/dL for acute attacks of mania and long-term maintenance?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.6 to 1.5 mEq/dL

 

Lithium has a narrow therapeutic window and its serum concentrations need careful monitoring.

 

0.6 to 1.5 mEq/dL represents the general therapeutic range for lithium. According to 12th edition of Synopsis of Psychiatry,  for acute manic episodes, the target serum lithium level is between 1.0 to 1.2 mEq/dL, while for long-term maintenance, it is 0.4 to 0.8 mEq/dL. The option closes to this range is option C.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.5 to 1 mEq/dL is close but not the typical therapeutic range. It is on the lower end and might not be effective for many patients, especially during acute mania.

 

Option B. 0.1 to 0.5 mEq/dL is subtherapeutic. Such low levels wouldn't be effective for the treatment of bipolar disorder and would not offer the necessary mood-stabilizing effects.

 

Option D. 2 to 3 mEq/dL is a toxic range. Lithium concentrations at this level can result in severe side effects and even life-threatening toxicity.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 655

questions.text: A male patient who just lost his work felt irritated and depressed for the majority of the time. Thinking about the future troubled him, and he was irritated with his family members. He went out to see movies with his friends on occasion and was able to enjoy himself, but when he returned home, he experienced identical sensations. What's the most likely diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adjustment disorder

 

The patient's symptoms – depressive mood, irritability, and worry about the future – began after a clear stressor, which in this case is the loss of his job. While he has some features of depression, the ability to temporarily feel better, such as when seeing movies with friends, makes a major depressive episode less likely.

 

This disorder arises within three months of a particular stressor (e.g., job loss) and resolves within six months after the stressor ends or the individual adapts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Generalized anxiety disorder: Chronic worry is a feature, but there is usually no specific identifiable stressor or precipitant, and the duration of symptoms should be at least 6 months.

 

Option C. Mixed anxiety with depression: This isn’t a specific DSM-5 diagnosis. While the patient has symptoms of both, the clear onset after job loss points more towards adjustment disorder.

 

Option D. Moderate depression: The patient’s ability to still experience pleasure (e.g., enjoying movies) makes a full depressive episode less likely.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Adjustment disorder is characterized by emotional responses to stressful events like financial problems, medical illness, relationship problems or death of a loved one. It manifests with emotional or behavioral symptoms which include depressed mood, anxiety, worry, a feeling of inability to cope and some degree of disturbance in individuals daily functioning. The symptoms typically remit within 6 months if the stressor has ended. Treatment of choice is supportive psychotherapy.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 112.

choices.text: Atypical antipsychotics is the first line treatment
Prevalence is 7 -10 percent in general population

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD)? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Depression is a common comorbidity

 

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a condition characterized by intrusive, repetitive thoughts (obsessions) and the urge to perform repetitive behaviors or rituals (compulsions).

 

Many individuals with OCD also suffer from depression. The two conditions can coexist and may even be related in some manner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atypical antipsychotics is the first line treatment: This is false. The first-line treatments for OCD are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), clomipramine and cognitive-behavioral therapy. Atypical antipsychotics may be added as an adjunctive treatment in patients who do not respond to standard treatments.

 

Option B. Prevalence is 7-10 percent in general population: This is incorrect. The prevalence of OCD in the general population is around 2-3%.

 

Option D. Contamination is an uncommon obsession: False. Contamination obsessions are the most common types of obsessions in OCD. Individuals may fear germs or becoming ill and may wash their hands excessively as a result.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

OCD is characterized by obsessions and compulsions. Life time prevalence is around 2-3% and is more common among females. Most common presentation is obsessive contamination with compulsive washing followed by pathological doubt with repeated checking. Most common comorbidity is depression. First line treatment includes SSRIs and chlomipramine. Atypical antipsychotics are used as adjunctive treatment.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 95-97.

choices.text: Reactive mood response to positive stimulus
Responds better to TCAs than MAO-I and SSRI

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of atypical depression? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Responds better to TCAs than MAO-I and SSRI

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased sleep: Individuals might sleep more than usual.

 

Option B. Reactive mood: While the individuals typically have a depressed mood, their mood can temporarily lift in response to positive events.

 

Option C. Heaviness of the body: Often described as "leaden paralysis," especially in the arms and legs.

 

However, the claim that atypical depression responds better to tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) than to monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAO-I) and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI) is incorrect. In reality, atypical depression often responds better to SSRIs & MAO-Is than to TCAs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Atypical depression, as its name implies, has features that deviate from classic presentations of depression. It is characterized by reversal of vegetative symptoms (i.e., increased sleep, appetite and weight), presence of mood reactivity, leaden paralysis (subjective feeling heaviness of limbs and difficulty in moving them) and extreme sensitivity to interpersonal rejection. SSRIs & MAO-Is have shown efficacy in treating atypical depression, making them a potential therapeutic option for this subtype.

 

Reference: Shorter Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 197.

questions.text: All of the following are components of Beck's cognitive theory of depression except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Introjection

 

Introjection is a psychological process where a person unconsciously adopts the ideas or attributes of other people or objects. This is often discussed in psychoanalytic contexts, not cognitive ones.

 

It involves internalizing aspects of others, such as a child internalizing aspects of a lost parent, leading to complex emotional outcomes, which might contribute to the development of depressive feelings.

 

Other Options:

 

Beck's cognitive theory of depression posits that negative thoughts, cognitive distortions, and dysfunctional beliefs are central to the development and maintenance of depression.

 

Option A. Dysfunctional beliefs are ingrained, maladaptive beliefs developed over time, often from childhood experiences, that can trigger depression when activated by stress.

 

Option B. Cognitive distortions are systematic errors in thinking, such as all-or-nothing thinking or overgeneralization, which negatively influence one's perception of reality.

 

Option D. Automatic negative thoughts are recurring negative thoughts that occur spontaneously and contribute to the persistence of depressive symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Introjection is not a component of Beck's cognitive theory of depression; it is associated with psychoanalytic theory, which focuses on internalized feelings towards an object, such as a parent, and is less commonly used in contemporary understanding of depression.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man who recently lost his wife complains that his intestines have rotted. He believes he is to blame for his wife's death and should be imprisoned. He complains that he is constantly depressed and has lost interest in daily activities since his wife's death. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG  2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psychotic depression

 

The patient's presentation of severe depressive symptoms (constant depression, anhedonia) combined with delusional beliefs (thinking his intestines have rotted, feeling culpable for his wife's death) is characteristic of psychotic depression. Psychotic depression, or major depressive disorder with psychotic features, is a subtype of major depression characterized by the presence of mood-congruent or mood-incongruent delusions or hallucinations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal grief reaction might involve feelings of sadness and even guilt, but it wouldn't typically involve delusions although transient hallucinations can be seen.

 

Option C. Delusional disorder involves holding one or more delusions in the absence of other psychiatric disorders. These individuals' functioning might not be notably impaired, and the delusions do not typically center around depressive themes.

 

Option D. Schizophrenia involves characteristic symptoms like hallucinations, delusions, disorganized speech or behavior, and negative symptoms. While depression can be a feature, the given presentation is more aligned with psychotic depression than with schizophrenia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Psychotic depression is seen in moderate to severe depressive disorder where the individual experiences both depressive symptoms and psychosis, such as delusions or hallucinations. These psychotic symptoms could be mood congruent (i.e, content of delusion/ hallucination is consistent with the depressed mood) or mood incongruent. Delusions in psychotic depression often revolve around themes of guilt, worthlessness, or illness.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 356, 360.

questions.text: A known alcoholic patient is brought to the emergency in a disoriented state. He complains of seeing snakes and insects crawling on his skin. Which of the following should be given to this patient? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lorazepam + thiamine

 

Explanation:

 

The patient is displaying signs of alcohol withdrawal, particularly delirium tremens (DTs) which is characterized by confusion, visual and tactile hallucinations (like seeing snakes and feeling bugs crawling on the skin), tremors, and autonomic hyperactivity.

 

  • Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine and is the treatment of choice for alcohol withdrawal, including DTs.
  • Thiamine is essential to administer before or alongside glucose administration to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy in alcohol-dependent individuals.

  • Haloperidol may be used to control severe agitation or hallucinations but is not a first-line therapy for DTs and could lower the seizure threshold.

     

Educational Objective: 

 

Alcohol withdrawal delirium (DTs) typically presents 48-72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucinations (especially visual), agitation, coarse tremors and autonomic hyperactivity. Risk factors include surgery, infections or other medical conditions. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention. Treatment includes intravenous lorazepam or diazepam with thiamine supplementation to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 631-632.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1

 

Explanation:

 

Let's match the descriptions to the terms:

 

A. Depression : "Difficult to diagnose due to the shell of physician’s pride" would suggest that physicians might not show or express their symptoms due to professional pride. So, A matches with 3.

 

B. Suicide : "Women physicians, substance abuse, relationship troubles" could be potential risk factors or associated factors. So, B matches with 4.

 

C. Burnout : "State of emotional and physical exhaustion caused by prolonged stress, relieved after relaxation" perfectly describes burnout. So, C matches with 2.

 

D. Overthinking : "The feeling goes away as soon as you leave the hospital" does not clearly correlate with overthinking, but given the other matches, this seems the closest fit. So, D matches with 1.

 

So, the correct matching would be:

 

A) A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 447, 764.

choices.text: Is commonly associated with concomitant hypothyroidism
Characterised by at least four distinct episodes per year

questions.text: Rapid cycling in bipolar disorder is characterised by all of the following features except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Occurs more commonly in men

 

  • Rapid cycling in bipolar disorder is defined by having four or more distinct mood episodes (mania, hypomania, or depression) within a single year.
  • This condition is more commonly observed in females.
  • Several factors, including hypothyroidism and substance abuse, can contribute to the likelihood of rapid cycling.
  • Additionally, the use of antidepressants has been found to increase the risk of triggering rapid cycling episodes.
  • Mood stabilizer of choice - Valproate

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Is commonly associated with concomitant hypothyroidism: This statement is correct. Hypothyroidism is known to be associated with an increased risk of rapid cycling in bipolar disorder.

 

Option C. Characterised by at least four distinct episodes per year: This statement is correct. The definition of rapid cycling specifically includes the occurrence of four or more mood episodes in one calendar year.

 

Option D. Antidepressants increase the likelihood: This statement is correct. The use of antidepressants can indeed increase the likelihood of rapid cycling in individuals with bipolar disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rapid cycling in bipolar disorder is more commonly seen in females and is characterized by at least four distinct episodes per year.

questions.text: Abrupt stoppage of which of the following drugs causes agitation, anxiety and insomnia? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Venlafaxine

 

Abrupt discontinuation or dose reduction of venlafaxine has been known to result in a discontinuation syndrome characterized by agitation, anxiety, and insomnia. This is particularly noted with venlafaxine because of its short half-life. While all the drugs listed can have withdrawal symptoms if stopped suddenly, venlafaxine is particularly associated with these symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Valproate: Abrupt discontinuation can lead to seizure recurrence in those using it as an antiepileptic and can cause relapse of mood symptoms in those using it as mood stabilizer.

 

Option B. Olanzapine: Stopping it can result in a return of psychotic symptoms.

 

Option C. Imipramine: It can cause withdrawal symptoms, but they are typically more varied and might include headache, nausea, and malaise.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The key features of antidepressant discontinuation syndrome, often abbreviated as FINISH:

 

  • Flu-like symptoms
  • Insomnia
  • Nausea
  • Imbalance
  • Sensory disturbances (e.g., electric shock sensations)
  • Hyperarousal (e.g., anxiety, agitation).

 

It is particularly common with SSRIs and SNRIs with shorter half-lives, such as venlafaxine (most common). Short acting SSRIs such as paroxetine and fluvoxamine are also commonly associated with discontinuation syndrome. Gradual tapering and patient education are essential to prevent and manage this syndrome.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 3150.

questions.text: A bashful young man who prefers social solitude appears emotionally frigid and lives alone. There is no history of delusions or hallucinations. The most likely explanation is? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Schizoid personality disorder

 

Schizoid personality disorder is marked by detachment from social relationships and a restricted range of emotional expression. Individuals prefer solitude and appear emotionally cold.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paranoid personality disorder: It is characterized by excessive suspiciousness and distrust of others. They may be excessively sensitive and give excessive importance to themselves. The vignette described above does not mention suspiciousness, infact mentions there is no history of delusions. Hence the answer is not paranoid personality disorder.

 

Option C. Antisocial personality disorder: These patients disregard others' rights and frequently violates them. They frequently get involved in unlawful behaviours such as theft, conning etc. 

 

Option D. Emotionally unstable personality disorder: Otherwise known as Borderline personality disorder. They are almost always in the state of crisis. They have a history of unstable relationships and emotions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Schizoid personality disorder is characterized by detachment from social relationships and prefer solitary activities. They are emotionally cold and are indifferent to praise or criticism. There is also an absence of close relationships. It is classified as a Cluster A personality disorder.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 2152

questions.text: What are the tactile hallucinations observed in instances of prolonged cocaine intoxication? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Formication

 

Formication, characterized by the feeling of insects moving beneath the skin, is a notable occurrence in cases of cocaine abuse. This phenomenon is also commonly denoted as Magnan's syndrome or cocaine bugs.

 

COCAINE

 

  • Derived from the plant, Erythroxylum coca
  • Sigmund Freud studied its pharmacological effects and probably had an addiction to cocaine too.
  • Was initially used as a local anaesthetic (as it blocks fast sodium channels), especially for ENT surgeries.
  • Blocks dopamine and norepinephrine receptors (dopamine & NE reuptake is inhibited) resulting in-
    • Vasoconstriction: HTN, MI
    • Nasal septal perforation (nasal inhalation of cocaine results in nasal congestion and long-term use can cause nasal septal perforation)
    • Seizures
    • Jet black pigmentation of tongue
  • Routes of administration - Snorting (inhalation of finely powdered form into the nose), freebasing (smoking), I.V. and subcutaneous.

 

Intoxication

 

  • Euphoria
  • Sympathetic symptoms (tachycardia, palpitations, hypertension, sweating, mydriasis)
  • Paranoid ideations (persecutory ideations) + auditory hallucinations
  • Tactile hallucinations or cocaine bugs or magnan phenomenon or formication (sensation of insects crawling under the skin)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oneroid state is a dream-like fantastic delusional derangement of consciousness

 

Option C. Dipsomania is a historical term describing a medical condition involving an uncontrollable craving for alcohol or drugs.

 

Option D. Carphologia is a lint-picking behavior that is often a symptom of a delirious state.

questions.text: What is an infrequent yet highly serious adverse outcome of clozapine that necessitates consistent monitoring?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Agranulocytosis

 

CLOZAPINE

 

  • Treatment-resistant schizophrenia (TRS)- Lack of response to at least two different antipsychotics, including at least one second-generation antipsychotic, given in adequate dosage and for an adequate duration (at least 4-6 weeks).
  • Clozapine is the drug of choice (DOC) in TRS.
  • Unique mechanism of action- More affinity for D4 than D2, hence causes minimal EPS.
  • Antipsychotic that causes max weight gain.
  • Clozapine is the only antipsychotic with antisuicide property.

 

Side effects of clozapine

 

  • Life-threatening: Agranulocytosis (idiosyncratic), myocarditis (idiosyncratic), seizures (dose-dependent)
  • Sedation (most common), sialorrhea
  • Syncope, hypotension, tachycardia, nausea, vomiting
  • Weight gain, anticholinergic side effects
  • Due to the possibility of agranulocytosis, when a patient is on clozapine, ANC and TLC monitoring is required.
  • The regime of monitoring-
    • First 6 months- Once a week
    • Next 6 months- Once in two weeks
    • After 1 year- Once in four weeks, till clozapine is continued 
  • Stop clozapine, if WBC < 3000/dl or ANC < 1500/dl
  • Contraindications for clozapine use
    • WBC < 3500/dl
    • History of agranulocytosis on clozapine
    • Use of other bone marrow suppressants like carbamazepine

choices.text: Small doses of regular consumption of alcohol

questions.text: A 48-year-old male presents to the ER with confusion and shaking of the entire body. He has a history of excessive alcohol consumption. What is the cause of delirium tremens in an alcoholic? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute infection

 

Delirium tremens is primarily caused by abrupt alcohol cessation in chronic users.

 

Acute infections can exacerbate or precipitate its onset.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fatty liver: Fatty liver doesn't directly precipitate DT.

 

Option C. Gradual withdrawal of alcohol: Gradual withdrawal typically avoids DT.

 

Option D. Small doses of regular consumption of alcohol: Regular small doses wouldn't lead to abrupt cessation symptoms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Alcohol withdrawal delirium (DTs) typically presents 48-72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucinations (especially visual), agitation, coarse tremors and autonomic hyperactivity. Risk factors include surgery, infections or other medical conditions. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention. Treatment includes intravenous lorazepam or diazepam with thiamine supplementation to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy.

 

Reference: Shorter Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 572-573.

choices.text: Triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia
Loss of long-term memory but intact personality
Anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory
Loss of implicit memory and immediate recall

questions.text: Which of the following is true statement about Korsakoff syndrome? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory

 

Korsakoff syndrome is a chronic memory disorder caused by severe deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1). The most common cause is alcohol misuse, but other conditions that affect nutrition can also lead to Korsakoff syndrome. Its main feature is anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory i.e., patients with Korsakoff syndrome can't acquire new information or recall recent events, but long-term memories from before the onset of the illness remain intact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia: Refers to Wernicke's encephalopathy, which often precedes Korsakoff syndrome and presents with a triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia. If left untreated, Wernicke's can progress to Korsakoff syndrome.

 

Option B. Loss of long-term memory but intact personality: While long-term memories may be affected in Korsakoff syndrome, it is not a characteristic feature. Personality changes, apathy, and lack of insight can be seen.

 

Option D. Loss of implicit memory and immediate recall: Korsakoff syndrome predominantly affects explicit memory (conscious recall of facts and events), not implicit memory (unconscious memory like skills).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Korsakoff syndrome is a chronic memory disorder caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. It is primarily associated with chronic alcohol misuse. It is characterized by anterograde amnesia (difficulty forming new memories) and often retrograde amnesia (loss of past memories). Confabulation is common, where patients fill memory gaps with fabricated information. Treatment involves thiamine replacement and abstaining from alcohol. It often follows or coexists with Wernicke's encephalopathy, which is an acute syndrome requiring immediate thiamine treatment.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 38-40.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a good prognostic factor in schizophrenia? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insidious onset of symptoms

 

Insidious onset of symptoms, where the symptoms develop slowly and subtly over time, tends to indicate a poorer prognosis when compared to an abrupt or sudden onset of symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Schizophrenia's prognosis varies based on several factors:

 

Option A. Positive symptoms: Positive symptoms such as hallucinations and delusions are usually more responsive to antipsychotic medications, marking them as a better prognostic factor.

 

Option B. Late age of onset: Late age of onset indeed is a better prognostic factor. Early-onset schizophrenia tends to be more severe and has a poorer prognosis than schizophrenia that begins in adulthood.

 

Option D. Associated with depression: If a patient with schizophrenia also has depressive symptoms, the prognosis might be somewhat better since affective symptoms might respond to treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 62.

questions.text: A drug that selectively reduces the reuptake of serotonin would likely cause which of the following side effects? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sexual dysfunction

 

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are a class of drugs that specifically inhibit the reuptake of serotonin. One of the well-documented side effects of SSRIs is sexual dysfunction, which may manifest as decreased libido, delayed ejaculation, anorgasmia, or erectile dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Constipation: Some antidepressants, particularly tricyclic antidepressants, can cause constipation, but it's not a primary side effect of SSRIs.

 

Option C. Sialorrhea: This refers to excessive drooling or salivation. It's not typically a side effect of SSRIs.

 

Option D. Visual disturbance: While many drugs can cause visual disturbances, it's not a hallmark side effect of SSRIs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Side effects of SSRIs include:

 

  • Most common: Nausea
  • Most common long-term side effects: Sexual dysfunction including delayed orgasm, poor erection and low libido.
  • CNS side effects- Paradoxical anxiety, sedation, vivid dreams, sweating, seizures, EPSE etc.
  • QTc prolongation
  • Weight gain

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 1018-1020.

questions.text: You are attending physiology viva. The examiner asks you who recorded the first EEG. You say "I don't know "The examiner feels bad for you and gives you a clue that "the name sounds like something you get commonly in McDonalds". You remember the name and answer correctly. What type of memory has been implicated here?" (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Priming

 

Priming is when exposure to a stimulus influences the response to a subsequent stimulus. In this scenario, the examiner's hint about McDonald's (suggesting "burger") facilitated the student's recall of "Berger," who recorded the first EEG.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Semantic memory: Semantic memory involves facts and general knowledge, like knowing the capital of a country.

 

Option B. Implicit memory: Implicit memory is unconscious, but involves skills or tasks, like riding a bike.

 

Option C. Associative learning: Associative learning involves pairing two stimuli, like Pavlov's dog experiment.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Priming means that a recent experience makes it easier for you to notice or identify something related.

 

Perceptual Priming: Recognizing something becomes easier because you've recently seen something that looks similar. For example, if you've just seen a picture of a lion, you'll be faster at spotting the word "lion" even if it's a bit unclear.

 

Conceptual Priming: Understanding or noticing something becomes easier because you've recently thought about a related idea. For example, if you've just read about rivers and banks, you'll probably guess the word "bank" when given "ban_" instead of thinking of "band."

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 116.

questions.text: Match the following (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-a, 2-b, 3-c, 4-d

 

  1. Eonism: a. Sexual gratification by cross-dressing. This term is used to describe individuals who derive sexual pleasure from dressing in clothes traditionally worn by the opposite gender.
  2. Frotteurism: b. The act of rubbing one's genitals against a non-consenting person, usually in a crowded place, such as public transport. It is considered a paraphilic disorder.
  3. Necrophilia: c. Sexual stimulation by corpses. This is a rare and extreme paraphilia where individuals are sexually aroused by deceased bodies.
  4. Algolagnia: d. Sexual gratification in inflicting or suffering pain. This can involve either sadism (inflicting pain) or masochism (receiving pain) as part of sexual activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eonism is sexual gratification by cross-dressing, frotteurism involves rubbing genitals against a non-consenting person, necrophilia is sexual stimulation by corpses, and algolagnia involves sexual gratification from inflicting or suffering pain.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in making a diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cognitive dysfunction

 

Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is diagnosed based on specific criteria that include impairments in social interaction and communication, as well as restrictive and repetitive patterns of behavior. Abnormalities in social communication and socialization, as well as restricted interests and behaviors, are key components of the diagnostic criteria for ASD. However, cognitive dysfunction, while it may be present in some individuals with ASD, is not a primary criterion used to diagnose the disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abnormalities in social communication: This statement is correct. Impaired social communication is a core feature of ASD and is part of the diagnostic criteria.

 

Option B. Abnormalities in socialisation: This statement is correct. Difficulties in socialization, which include challenges in social interaction, are also part of the diagnostic criteria for ASD.

 

Option C. Restriction in interests and behaviour: This statement is correct. Restrictive, repetitive patterns of behavior and interests are essential criteria for diagnosing ASD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of Autism Spectrum Disorder includes impairments in social interaction, social communication, and restrictive, repetitive behaviors, but not cognitive dysfunction.

questions.text: La belle indifference is seen in which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Conversion disorder

 

La Belle indifference can be seen in Conversion disorder.

 

CONVERSION DISORDER

 

ICD-11 uses the term ‘dissociative neurological symptom disorder’

 

  • Patients present with symptoms suggestive of motor, sensory or cognitive deficits; however, no neurological cause can be found.
  • Also, the symptoms do not conform to the anatomical and physiological principles

 

Patients may have ‘la belle indifference’, which is a lack of concern for the symptoms. E.g., A patient with sudden onset loss of vision in an eye may appear unconcerned with her symptom.

choices.text: Stop the drug and proceed drug free

questions.text: A pregnant female with bipolar disorder with previous history of 4 episodes and no episode for the past 1 year, well controlled with 750 mg Lithium, now in the third trimester , comes to the psychiatrist. What is the next step in management ? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decrease dose

 

Lithium doses may need adjustment during pregnancy due to changes in renal clearance, especially in the third trimester, to minimize toxicity risks while maintaining therapeutic effects.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase dose: Increasing the dose isn't recommended due to increased risk of lithium toxicity in the later stages of pregnancy.

 

Option C. Switch to valproate: Switching to valproate is not advised due to its high teratogenic risk, especially for neural tube defects.

 

Option D. Stop the drug and proceed drug free: Stopping lithium abruptly can lead to a high risk of relapse in bipolar disorder; it's important to manage it carefully.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

During pregnancy, especially in the third trimester, it's crucial to carefully manage lithium dosage to balance efficacy with safety, avoiding both relapse and toxicity.

questions.text: A new IT employee is feeling guilty, miserable, and unable to concentrate on his task. His symptoms began three years ago, when he began college. The following is the most likely diagnosis: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dysthymia

 

The patient's symptoms of guilt, misery, and concentration issues lasting three years are indicative of dysthymia (Persistent Depressive Disorder).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Depressive disorder: At least 5 out of 9 symptoms should be present to diagnose depressive disorders which include: sad mood, loss of interest, guilt or worthlessness, lack of energy, poor concentration, increased or decreased appetite, increased or decreased psychomotor activity, increased or decreased sleep, and suicidal thoughts. The patient described above has only two of the above three symptoms. Patients with dysthymia have lesser symptoms and also the social occupational dysfunction is lesser in comparison to depressive disorder.

 

Option C. Adjustment disorder: It is characterized by emotional responses to stressful situations such as financial problems, medical illness, relationship problems etc. The symptoms range from anxiety to depressive symptoms. Symptoms usually last no longer than six months after removal of the stressor

 

Option D. Cyclothymia: It is a milder form of bipolar disorder, in which fluctuations between hypomania and mild depressive symptoms occur, but they are never severe enough to make a diagnosis of mania/hypomania or depression. The above described features do not mention any hypomanic symptoms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Dysthymia is characterized by chronic, less severe depressive symptoms lasting at least two years. Symptoms should not even be severe enough to meet the criteria of mild depressive disorder. (Subsyndromal depression >2 years duration). If the depressive disorder continues for more than 2 years, it is known as chronic depression.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 73.

choices.text: Varenicline comes with a black box warning of cardiovascular death
There should be a 15-minute gap between nicotine gum and coffee/soda/acidic food as they decrease its absorption
Nicotine chewing gum is better for constant use as it gives 25% higher blood level than lozenges

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding nicotine substitution therapy? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) There should be a 15-minute gap between nicotine gum and coffee/soda/acidic food as they decrease its absorption.

 

 Acidic beverages can interfere with nicotine gum's absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preferably given by gastrointestinal route: Incorrect. NRT is not given via the gastrointestinal route. Nicotine in NRT is absorbed either through buccal mucosa or skin.

 

Option B. Varenicline comes with a black box warning of cardiovascular death: Incorrect. Varenicline doesn’t come with this black box warning.

 

Option D. Nicotine chewing gum is better for constant use as it gives 25% higher blood level than lozenges: Incorrect. Choice between gum and lozenges depends on individual preference, not blood levels.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) is an effective method to assist in smoking cessation. It is used to relieve craving for tobacco by substituting nicotine in tobacco with nicotine in safer forms. Various preparations include nicotine gums, nicotine lozenges, nicotine patch, nicotine spray and nicotine inhaler. Nicotine gum's absorption can be affected by acidic beverages, so it's advised to avoid them shortly before or while using the gum.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 684.

choices.text: Observe the patient for 2 hours post meal
Ask the psychiatrist to prescribe anti-anxiety medication
Increase the calories from 1500 to 2000 in her diet

questions.text: A patient of anorexia nervosa was eating all her meals according to the prescribed diet chart but there is no change in her weight after 1 week. Which of the following needs to be done? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Observe the patient for 2 hours post meal

 

A lack of weight gain in an anorexia nervosa patient adhering to a diet can suggest surreptitious purging behaviors:

 

Observe the patient for 2 hours post meal: This helps in ensuring the patient isn't purging post-meal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anti-anxiety medication: Anxiety is common in anorexia but doesn't directly address potential purging.

 

Option C. Increase calories: Confirm proper consumption and retention before adjusting calories.

 

Option D. Increase water intake: This won't address the primary concern and may introduce other issues.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In patients with anorexia nervosa who are not gaining weight despite adherence to a meal plan, it's important to first rule out surreptitious purging behaviors. Observing the patient post-meal can help ensure that they are not engaging in behaviors like vomiting or excessive exercise after eating.

 

Reference: Shorter Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 320.

questions.text: A patient believes he is the most important person in the world, his neighbors and family members are attempting to hurt him out of jealousy. His wife claims contrary, claiming that he has only recently begun acting in this manner, and that he previously worked calmly as a school teacher. He's probably suffering from? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Delusion of grandiosity and persecution

 

The patient's belief that he is the most important person in the world indicates a delusion of grandiosity. His belief that his neighbors and family members are attempting to hurt him due to jealousy represents a delusion of persecution. Both types of delusions are present in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delusion of grandiosity: Delusion of grandiosity is evident, but this choice doesn't encompass the persecutory beliefs he holds.

 

Option B. Delusion of persecution: While the patient does display delusions of persecution, this choice neglects the grandiose delusion.

 

Option D. Delusion of grandiosity, persecution and reference: The patient clearly exhibits delusions of grandiosity and persecution, but there's no evidence in the provided information suggesting a delusion of reference.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Delusional disorders are characterized by the presence of one or more delusions that persist for at least one month.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 245-246.

questions.text:
A persistent alcoholic patient presents with convulsions and impaired sensorium. He has been drinking for ten years and consumes 24 units every day. His most recent drink was two days ago. He is discovered to have auditory hallucinations as well as secondary delusions. What method will you employ to manage this patient?

 

  1. Diazepam
  2. Thiamine
  3. Naltrexone
  4. Flupenthixol depot injection
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2

 

The patient is presenting with symptoms of alcohol withdrawal, specifically delirium tremens, characterized by tremors, altered sensorium, hallucinations, seizures, and agitation.

 

1. Diazepam: Benzodiazepines, like diazepam, are the first line of treatment for alcohol withdrawal symptoms and can help reduce the severity of symptoms, prevent seizures, and can be titrated based on the severity of withdrawal.

 

2. Thiamine: Chronic alcoholics are at risk for thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency, leading to Wernicke's encephalopathy. It is important to administer thiamine before or with the first dose of glucose-containing fluids or foods to prevent precipitating or exacerbating Wernicke's encephalopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Naltrexone: This is an opioid antagonist that is used to decrease alcohol cravings. It is not directly useful in treating acute withdrawal symptoms.

 

4. Flupenthixol depot injection: This is an antipsychotic medication. It is not the primary treatment for alcohol withdrawal.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Alcohol withdrawal delirium (DTs) typically presents 48-72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucinations (especially visual), agitation, coarse tremors and autonomic hyperactivity. Risk factors include surgery, infections or other medical conditions. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention. Treatment includes intravenous lorazepam or diazepam with thiamine supplementation to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy.

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 472-473.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is suffering from selective mutism. He is most probably suffering from? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Childhood anxiety disorder

 

Selective mutism is an anxiety disorder where a child speaks in some settings (like home) but consistently remains silent in others (like school).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Childhood depression: Children with depression might withdraw but don't exhibit selective mutism.

 

Option B. Childhood psychosis: Psychosis presents with hallucinations or delusions, not selective mutism.

 

Option D. Hyperkinetic disorder: ADHD involves inattention or hyperactivity, not selective silence in specific scenarios.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Selective mutism is an anxiety disorder characterized by a child's consistent failure to speak in specific situations, despite being able to speak in others.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 3719.

questions.text: Which of the following disease is exclusively seen in females? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rett syndrome

 

Rett syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that affects brain development and results in severe intellectual and physical disability. It is nearly always seen in females. Males with the genetic mutation for Rett syndrome usually die shortly after birth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Asperger syndrome: It is a milder variant of autism and can occur in both males and females, although it is more commonly diagnosed in males.

 

Option C. Selective mutism: An anxiety disorder in which a person who is normally capable of speech cannot speak in specific situations or to specific people. It affects both males and females.

 

Option D. Atypical autism: Also known as Pervasive Developmental Disorder - Not Otherwise Specified (PDD-NOS), it can occur in both males and females.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Rett syndrome is a rare genetic neurodevelopmental disorder almost exclusively seen in females. It is caused by mutations in the MECP2 gene located on the X chromosome. It is characterized by normal development for the first 6-18 months of life followed by a loss of purposeful hand skills, severe language impairment, and motor abnormalities.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 165.

questions.text:
Which of the following are features of Korsakoff syndrome? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. Confabulation
  2. Amnesia
  3. Peripheral neuropathy
  4. Ophthalmoplegia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

Korsakoff syndrome is a chronic memory disorder most commonly caused by severe deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1). It is often associated with alcohol misuse, but can also be caused by other conditions. The primary features of Korsakoff syndrome include:

 

1. Confabulation: Patients often create false memories or stories to fill in gaps in their memory. These are not intentional lies, but rather attempts to make sense of their memory loss.

 

2. Amnesia: This involves significant memory impairment. Anterograde amnesia (difficulty forming new memories) is more prominent than retrograde amnesia (difficulty recalling past memories).

 

3. Peripheral neuropathy: This is also seen in Korsakoff syndrome, involving nerve damage that can cause pain, numbness, or weakness, typically in the hands and feet.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Ophthalmoplegia: This is not a feature of Korsakoff syndrome. Ophthalmoplegia, or paralysis of the eye muscles, is a characteristic of Wernicke's encephalopathy, which often precedes Korsakoff syndrome but is a separate condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Korsakoff syndrome is characterized by amnesia, confabulation, and peripheral neuropathy, but not ophthalmoplegia, which is associated with Wernicke's encephalopathy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has a history of urinating in public without having any remorse for it. She also has difficulty in getting motivated and has mild memory deficits. Which of the following lobes may be affected? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Frontal

 

The frontal lobe is responsible for executive functions, social behavior, motivation, and impulse control. Damage to the frontal lobe can result in disinhibited behaviors, such as socially inappropriate actions (e.g., urinating in public without remorse), lack of motivation (apathy), and mild memory impairments. These changes are often seen in conditions affecting the frontal lobe, including frontal lobe syndrome or neurodegenerative diseases. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parietal Lobe: Primarily responsible for sensation and spatial processing. Lesions here might manifest as sensory deficits or spatial disorientation, rather than the behavioral issues described.

 

Option B. Occipital Lobe: Concerned with vision. Deficits or lesions here primarily manifest as visual disturbances, not behavioral or motivational issues.

 

Option D. Temporal Lobe: Associated with auditory processing, memory, and emotion. Although it does play a role in memory, the other symptoms described are more consistent with frontal lobe dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Frontal Lobe is involved in executive functions, decision-making, motivation, and socially appropriate behavior. Damage can lead to disinhibited behavior, apathy, and memory deficits.

 

 

Reference: Shorter Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 346-348.

questions.text: A patient has the freedom to pick his or her caretaker and future course of action in treatment under the Mental Health Care Act of 2017. What is the name of this provision? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Advance directive

 

Under the Mental Health Care Act of 2017 in India, the provision allowing a patient to choose his or her caretaker and future course of action in treatment is termed the “Advance directive”. It is a legal document wherein the individual specifies the type of treatment they want or don't want, should they become mentally ill and be unable to make competent decisions in the future.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treatment directive, Option B. Mental will, and Option C. Future directive are not the correct terms used in the context of the Mental Health Care Act of 2017.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Under the Mental Health Care Act 2017 in India, individuals can use an "Advance Directive" to state the way they wish to be treated for a mental illness and the way they wish not to be treated for a mental illness. This provision empowers individuals to have a say in their treatment even if they become incapacitated in the future. This is applicable only if a person loses the capacity to make mental healthcare or treatment decisions. Individuals can also appoint “Nominated Representative (NR)”, who will help in taking decisions regarding the treatment if he or she loses the capacity to make decision.

 

Reference: Forensic Psychiatry in India, Interface of Indian Laws and Mental Health, Page No 42.

questions.text: A patient was started on Amitryptiline and he was found to be unconscious. Which of the following doesn’t suggest TCA toxicity ?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypothermia

 

TCA toxicity typically presents with hyperthermia due to anticholinergic effects, not hypothermia.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arrhythmias: Arrhythmias are a hallmark of TCA toxicity, reflecting its impact on cardiac conductivity.

 

Option B. Confusion: Confusion or altered sensorium is common due to the central nervous system effects of TCAs.

 

Option D. Pupillary dilatation: Pupillary dilatation results from the anticholinergic properties of TCAs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In cases of TCA toxicity, we see symptoms like arrhythmias, confusion, and pupillary dilatation due to its anticholinergic and cardiotoxic properties. Hypothermia is not typically associated with TCA overdose.

questions.text: In this case, a young boy is exhibiting symptoms of reduced mood, decreased energy, and diminished engagement with his environment. He has refrained from eating for the past week and his thoughts include phrases like "I have lost my mind. I am deceased. How can I consume food?". What is the specific delusion in this scenario? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nihilistic delusion

 

Nihilistic delusion (delusion of negation, Cotard syndrome): Patients may deny the existence of their body, their mind, or the world in general. For example, a patient with severe depression claimed that all his internal organs have rotted.

 

Here, the best answer is Nihilistic delusion rather than Cotard syndrome because the question has specifically asked the type of delusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypochondriacal delusion: Hypochondriacal delusion is an illness anxiety disorder. It is characterized by a preoccupation with having or acquiring a serious physical illness. The preoccupation persists despite normal investigations and medical reassurances.

 

Option D. Bizarre delusion: Scientifically impossible and culturally implausible (un-understandable). For example, a patient claimed that aliens stole his heart and lungs, and now he is living without those organs.

questions.text: All of the following side effects are more commonly seen with carbamezapine than oxcarbazepine , except ?  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyponatremia

 

Hyponatremia is more commonly associated with oxcarbazepine than carbamazepine. Oxcarbazepine induces this through its effect on renal handling of water by affecting antidiuretic hormone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rashes: Rashes are more common with carbamazepine due to its propensity to cause allergic skin reactions.

 

Option C. Blood dyscrasias: Blood dyscrasias, including agranulocytosis and aplastic anemia, are more associated with carbamazepine.

 

Option D. Hepatitis: Hepatitis and other liver dysfunctions are more often linked to carbamazepine than oxcarbazepine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While both carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine can cause similar side effects, hyponatremia is notably more prevalent with oxcarbazepine.

questions.text:
A pregnant mother was on SSRIs. The risk of which of the following is increased in the newborn? (INICET Nov 2022)

  1. Low APGAR score.
  2. ADHD.
  3. Persistent pulmonary hypertension.
  4. Delayed developmental milestones.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a, b, c, d

 

Explanation:

 

a. Low APGAR score: SSRIs in late pregnancy can lead to neonatal adaptation syndrome, impacting the APGAR score.

 

b. ADHD: Some research suggests a potential link between prenatal SSRI exposure and ADHD.

 

c. Persistent pulmonary hypertension: Late-pregnancy SSRI exposure is associated with this risk.

 

d. Delayed developmental milestones: There's some evidence linking SSRIs to delayed milestones, though it's less consistent.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

SSRIs during pregnancy are linked to multiple neonatal risks. They may increase the risk of cardiac birth defects, decreased gestational age, spontaneous abortion, decreased birth weight, suboptimal fetal growth, low APGAR scores, autism spectrum disorders, ADHD and persistent pulmonary hypertension (SSRIs and SNRIs).

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 687-688

choices.text: Acuity of onset and loss of consciousness

questions.text: Which of the following features differentiate delirium from dementia in Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acuity of onset and loss of consciousness

 

Delirium is characterized by an acute and fluctuating onset with disturbances in consciousness and attention. Dementia, such as Alzheimer's disease, has a gradual, insidious onset and is primarily a disorder of memory without loss of consciousness.

 

Delirium and dementia, though distinct syndromes, can sometimes overlap in presentation, making differentiation challenging. However, some key features can help differentiate the two:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acuity of onset and agitation: While the acuity of onset can differentiate the two, both delirium and dementia can be associated with agitation.

 

Option C. Visual hallucinations and impaired memory: Visual hallucinations are more common in delirium and some types of dementia like Lewy Body Dementia but not necessarily Alzheimer's disease. Impaired memory is a feature of dementia, primarily Alzheimer's, but can also be present in delirium.

 

Option D. Agitation and irritation: Both can be seen in either delirium or dementia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 22.

choices.text: Occurs gradually over a period of time

questions.text: Which of the following features is more in favor of delirium? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fluctuating course

 

Delirium is characterized by an acute onset and a fluctuating course, often varying in severity throughout the day.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Occurs gradually over a period of time: This is more suggestive of dementia rather than delirium.

 

Option C. Preserved consciousness: The characteristic feature of delirium is a disturbance in consciousness and attention. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

 

Option D. Commonly associated with auditory hallucinations: While hallucinations can be present in delirium, they aren't specific to it. Schizophrenia or other psychotic disorders might also present with auditory hallucinations.

 

Therefore, a fluctuating course is the most suggestive of delirium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delirium is the most common organic mental disorder. It has an acute onset with a fluctuating course. It is most commonly seen in elderly population. It is characterized by disturbed consciousness, and altered attention. Disturbances of sleep-wake cycle, evening worsening of symptoms (sundowning), and floccillations can be seen.

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook osf Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 22.

questions.text: A patient was prescribed escitalopram. Which of the following adverse effect is the least likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sialorrhea

 

Escitalopram is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). 

 

Sialorrhea is not typically associated with SSRIs. They are more likely to cause dry mouth. Sialorrhea is a common side effect of clozapine

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nausea: Nausea is a common side effect of SSRIs.

 

Option B. Vivid dreams: Vivid dreams can occasionally be reported but are not the most common side effect.

 

Option C. Anorgasmia: Anorgasmia or other sexual side effects are also commonly associated with SSRIs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Side effects of SSRIs include:

 

  • Most common: Nausea
  • Most common long-term side effects: Sexual dysfunction including delayed orgasm, poor erection and low libido.
  • CNS side effects- Paradoxical anxiety, sedation, vivid dreams, sweating, seizures, EPSE etc.
  • QTc prolongation
  • Weight gain

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 3156-3158

choices.text: Bladder training, with reward for delaying micturition during daytime
Bell and pad based classical conditioning

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presented with complaints of bed-wetting almost twice a week for the past 1 year. A detailed investigation was done to rule out the organic cause. What should be the treatment plan for this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bell and pad based classical conditioning

 

This is a first-line behavioral treatment for primary nocturnal enuresis. It involves an alarm that sounds when wetness is detected, conditioning the child to awaken and use the toilet.

 

Other Options:

 

The child described seems to have primary nocturnal enuresis, which is common in children and often has no organic cause:

 

Option A. Pharmacotherapy with imipramine: This is an option, but it's usually reserved for cases that don't respond to first-line treatments because of potential side effects.

 

Option B. Psychodynamic psychotherapy: Not typically used as a first-line treatment for nocturnal enuresis.

 

Option C. Bladder training: This focuses on delaying micturition during daytime, which is beneficial but not considered as the treatment of choice

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Sleep related enuresis is defined as voiding of urine at inappropriate places. It is nocturnal in around 80% of cases. The most common cause of bed wetting are psychosocial such as sibling rivalry. The treatment of choice is bed alarms. Drug of choice is desmopressin. Another medication which can be used is imipramine.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 169.

questions.text: A patient was prescribed escitalopram. Which of the following adverse effect is the least likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sialorrhea

 

Sialorrhea is not typically associated with SSRIs. They are more likely to cause dry mouth. Sialorrhea is a common side effect of clozapine.

 

Other Options:

 

Escitalopram is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). Among the options:

 

Option A. Nausea: Nausea is a common side effect of SSRIs.

 

Option B. Vivid dreams: Vivid dreams can occasionally be reported but are not the most common side effect.

 

Option C. Anorgasmia: Anorgasmia or other sexual side effects are also commonly associated with SSRIs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Side effects of SSRIs include:

 

  • Most common: Nausea
  • Most common long-term side effects: Sexual dysfunction including delayed orgasm, poor erection and low libido.
  • CNS side effects- Paradoxical anxiety, sedation, vivid dreams, sweating, seizures, EPSE etc.
  • QTc prolongation
  • Weight gain

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 3156-3158

questions.text: A person often feels that his hands are contaminated and he is forced to wash his hands. Recently, he feels this repetitive, distressing thought of repetitive hand washing has begun affecting his performance. Which of the following is the best treatment option for this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Exposure and response prevention

 

The patient's symptoms are consistent with Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD). One of the most effective treatments for OCD is Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP), which is a type of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) specific for OCD.

 

Exposure and response prevention is the mainstay treatment for OCD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DBT (Dialectical Behavior Therapy): DBT is primarily used for borderline personality disorder and other self-harming behaviors.

 

Option C. Systematic desensitization: Systematic desensitization is a behavioral technique mainly used to treat phobias by gradually exposing the patient to the phobic stimulus.

 

Option D. CBT (Cognitive Behavioral Therapy): CBT is a broader therapeutic technique and is used in a variety of psychiatric disorders.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

For OCD, Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP), a specialized form of CBT, is the evidence-based first-line treatment. It involves exposing patients to their obsessional triggers while refraining from performing their compulsive rituals, gradually reducing the distress elicited by obsessions.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 425.

choices.text: Suicide occurring at the time when the patient starts to recover
Suicide after taking low dose of drug

questions.text: Which of the following best describes paradoxical suicide? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Suicide occurring at the time when the patient starts to recover

 

Paradoxical suicide refers to the situation where a patient, who has been depressed and possibly suicidal, begins to show signs of improvement or recovery and then commits suicide. This paradox may occur because as the patient starts to recover, they regain some of their energy and motivation, which they might then use to act on their previously existing suicidal thoughts.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

About 2/3rd of patients with depression have suicidal ideation and 10-15% die by suicide. Patients with depressive disorders are at increased risk of suicide as they begin to improve and regain the energy needed to plan and carry out a suicide, this is known as Paradoxical suicide.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 366.

questions.text: Which of the following mood stabilizers causes hepatitis ? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Valproate

 

Valproate is known to cause hepatotoxicity, thus it is essential to monitor liver function tests regularly in patients taking valproate, especially during the initial months of therapy.

 

 

Educational Objective :

 

Valproate, a commonly used mood stabilizer in bipolar disorder, is associated hepatitis. Regular monitoring of liver function tests is crucial in patients on valproate therapy to detect and manage potential liver damage early.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl has intense food cravings. She consumes a large amount of food, followed by self-induced vomiting. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bulimia nervosa

 

The patient's behavior of consuming excessive amounts of food (binge eating) followed by self-induced vomiting (a purging behavior) is characteristic of Bulimia nervosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anorexia nervosa typically involves restriction of food intake leading to significantly low body weight and a fear of gaining weight. Binge eating and purging can also occur in anorexia nervosa, and this question should have ideally provided more information; with the imited information provided, bulimia nervosa is a better answer as it is characterised by binging and purging.

 

Option C. Atypical depression is a subtype of major depression and is not characterized by binge eating and purging, although increased appetite is seen.

 

Option D. Binge eating disorder involves episodes of overeating but without the regular purging behaviors seen in Bulimia nervosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bulimia nervosa is an eating disorder characterized by episodes of binge eating followed by inappropriate behaviors such as self-induced vomiting (purging) or hypergymnasia to prevent weight gain. It is usually associated with fear of gaining weight. Purging can lead to dental caries, knuckle callouses, parotitis, hypokalemic and hypochloremic alkalosis and rarely gastric or esophageal tear. Weight is usually normal, which differentiates from anorexia nervosa. Treatment includes CBT and SSRIs.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 469

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman considers chopping her fingers; she plots and imagines doing so but never accomplishes it. She claims she feels no shame for having such thoughts. Furthermore, she claims that the ideas are disturbing her and that she is unable to control them. The thoughts can stop with a seizure or gradually fade away on their own. Which of the following is the root of the problem? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Forced thinking

 

The patient is experiencing intrusive thoughts that she recognizes as her own but finds distressing and cannot control. The key detail here that differentiates from classic OCD is that these thoughts can stop with a seizure. This phenomenon is called ‘forced thinking’ which is a form of psychic aura.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thought insertion: Thought insertion refers to the belief that one's thoughts are being placed into their mind by an external force.

 

Option C. Crowding of thoughts: Crowding of thoughts refers to the rapid succession of multiple thoughts, typically seen in conditions like mania.

 

Option D. Obsession: Obsession in the context of OCD does involve intrusive, distressing thoughts, but these wouldn't typically cease with a seizure.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Forced thinking is a type of psychic aura which is characterized by recurrent intrusive thoughts, or ideas, which subside on seizure activity.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 510.

questions.text: Under the Mental Health Care Act 2017, a patient has the right to choose his or her caretaker and future course of action in treatment. What is this provision known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Advance directive

 

The Mental Health Care Act 2017 introduced a provision allowing individuals to specify in advance the manner in which they would like to be cared for and treated in the event they develop a mental illness in the future. This provision is called an "Advance Directive." The advance directive allows a person to specify how they want to be treated, what treatments they don't want, and to nominate a person to be their representative.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Under the Mental Health Care Act 2017 in India, individuals can use an "Advance Directive" to state the way they wish to be treated for a mental illness and the way they wish not to be treated for a mental illness. This provision empowers individuals to have a say in their treatment even if they become incapacitated in the future. This is applicable only if a person loses the capacity to make mental healthcare or treatment decisions. Individuals can also appoint “Nominated Representative (NR)”, who will help in taking decisions regarding the treatment if he or she loses the capacity to make decision.

 

Reference: Forensic Psychiatry in India, Interface of Indian Laws and Mental Health, Page No 42.

choices.text: Usually, terminates in awakening followed by confusion.
There may be neurological conditions associated.

questions.text: What is the false statement regarding somnambulism? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Person will have full consciousness.

 

Individuals who are sleepwalking typically act without conscious awareness and usually have no memory of the episode upon awakening.

 

Other Options:

 

Somnambulism, also known as sleepwalking, is a disorder of arousal from slow-wave sleep.

 

Option A. Disorder of sleep arousal: True. Sleepwalking arises from deep, non-REM (NREM) stage 4 sleep, making it a disorder of arousal.

 

Option C. Usually, terminates in awakening followed by confusion: True. When sleepwalkers are awakened, they are often disoriented and confused.

 

Option D. There may be neurological conditions associated: True. While many cases of somnambulism have no clear cause, certain neurological conditions can be associated with it.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Sleepwalking (somnambulism) is an arousal disorder originating from deep, non-REM stage 4 sleep. Individuals who sleepwalk typically act without conscious awareness and have no memory of the episode upon awakening. The person who is having sleep walking is difficult to awake.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 555.

questions.text: Which of the following is not classified as OCD as per ICD 11? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) PTSD

 

The International Classification of Diseases (ICD-11), like the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), classifies a number of disorders under the umbrella of obsessive-compulsive and related disorders. However, PTSD (Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder) is not classified as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11. Instead, it's classified under trauma- and stressor-related disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichotillomania: This is classified as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11.

 

Option B. Body dysmorphic disorder: This too is categorized as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11.

 

Option C. Hypochondriac disorder: Now termed "Illness Anxiety Disorder" in DSM-5, this is categorized as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obsessive-compulsive or related disorders in ICD-11 are classified as:

 

  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder
  • Body dysmorphic disorder
  • Olfactory reference disorder
  • Hypochondriasis
  • Hoarding disorder
  • Trichotillomania
  • Excoriation disorder

 

Reference: International Classification of Diseases, 11th edition, Page No 43-47

choices.text: It most commonly affects ages 35-45 years
Type 1 is common in both sexes
Attempt to commit suicide is seen around 15% of people

questions.text: Which of the following is false about bipolar disorder? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It most commonly affects ages 35-45 years

 

Bipolar disorder, historically called manic-depressive illness, often begins in late adolescence or early adulthood. While it can start in childhood or later in life, this is less common.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Type 1 is common in both sexes: True. Bipolar I disorder has no gender bias and affects men and women equally.

 

Option C. Prevalence in the general population is 1-2%: True. Bipolar disorder affects about 1-2% of the global population.

 

Option D. Attempt to commit suicide is seen in around 15% of people: True. People with bipolar disorder have a high suicide risk, and approximately 15% may end up taking their own life.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bipolar disorder typically presents in late adolescence or early adulthood. It is characterized by episodes of mania and depression, affects both sexes equally, has a prevalence of 1-2% in the general population, and carries a significant risk of suicide.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 376.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female comes to the OPD with complaints of “feeling tensed” and having “stomach upset” symptoms, including heartburn and diarrhea. She states that she has been having these symptoms since she was 25 years old and that her family members are also usually tense and “nervous.” Which of the following symptoms are also likely to be present in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tingling of extremities

 

The patient presents with symptoms of anxiety, including constant feelings of tension, gastrointestinal symptoms like heartburn and diarrhea, and a family history of similar symptoms, suggesting a diagnosis of Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD). GAD often includes somatic symptoms, such as tingling of the extremities, due to hyperventilation or heightened nervous system activity associated with anxiety.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ideas of Reference: This symptom is typically associated with psychotic disorders, such as schizophrenia or delusional disorders, where the patient believes that events, objects, or other people have a special and personal significance. This is not characteristic of GAD.

 

Option C. Hallucinations: Hallucinations involve sensory perceptions without external stimuli and are common in psychotic disorders, such as schizophrenia, but not in anxiety disorders.

 

Option D. Neologisms: Neologisms are newly coined words or phrases that have meaning only to the person using them and are commonly seen in formal thought disorders like schizophrenia. This is not a symptom seen in GAD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) may experience somatic symptoms like tingling of extremities due to heightened anxiety and nervous system activity.

questions.text: A young patient with acute psychosis is admitted to the hospital. He wakes up and asks for his wife, even though she is in the same room as him. When she is pointed out, he claims that she is not his wife and that she is being impersonated by someone else. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Capgras syndrome

 

The described scenario involves the patient's belief that a familiar person, in this case his wife, has been replaced by an imposter. This specific delusion is characteristic of Capgras syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fregoli syndrome: Fregoli syndrome is a delusional misidentification syndrome where the patient believes that a familiar persons can change his physical appearance and disguise as a stranger, and that he can take multiple different appearances.

 

Option C. Delusion of subjective doubles: Delusion of subjective doubles refers to the patient's belief that he or she has many doubles who are living life of their own.

 

Option D. Othello syndrome: Othello syndrome pertains to the delusional belief that one's partner is unfaithful.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Delusional misidentification syndromes include Capgras syndrome, Fregoli’s syndrome, syndrome of intermetamorphosis and syndrome of subjective doubles.

 

 

Reference: Sim’s Symptoms in the Mind, 7th edition, Page No 124-125.

questions.text: Match the following? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-2, B-4, C-1, D-3

 

Explanation:

 

Twilight (A) refers to a transient, impaired state of consciousness often seen during seizures or certain other medical conditions. Therefore, it matches with Impaired level of consciousness (2).

 

Oneroid state (B) is a term used in psychiatry to describe a dream-like state of consciousness, hence matching with Oneirophrenia (4), which is derived from the words meaning 'dream' and 'mind'.

 

Oligophrenia (C) is an outdated medical term used to describe intellectual disability or subnormal intelligence. Thus, it matches with Subnormal intelligence (1).

 

Paranoid Ideation (D) involves thoughts dominated by ideas of persecution or conspiracy against the individual. This matches with Persecution (3).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Oneroid state is characterized by a dream-like state resembling Oneirophrenia. Oligophrenia refers to intellectual disability, and Paranoid Ideation is centered on ideas of persecution.

 

Reference: Sim’s symptoms in the Mind, 7th edition, Page No 39, 40, 132; Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 4599.

questions.text: A young male who is shy and prefers social isolation appears to be emotionally cold and resides alone. There is no history of hallucinations or delusions. The most likely diagnosis is: (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Schizoid personality disorder

 

Schizoid personality disorder is marked by detachment from social relationships and a restricted range of emotional expression. Individuals prefer solitude and appear emotionally cold.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paranoid personality disorder: It is characterized by excessive suspiciousness and distrust of others. They may be excessively sensitive and give excessive importance to themselves. The vignette described above does not mention suspiciousness, infact mentions there is no history of delusions. Hence the answer is not paranoid personality disorder.

 

Option C. Antisocial personality disorder: These patients disregard others' rights and frequently violates them. They frequently get involved in unlawful behaviours such as theft, conning etc. 

 

Option D. Emotionally unstable personality disorder: Otherwise known as Borderline personality disorder. They are almost always in the state of crisis. They have a history of unstable relationships and emotions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Schizoid personality disorder is characterized by detachment from social relationships and prefer solitary activities. They are emotionally cold and are indifferent to praise or criticism. There is also an absence of close relationships. It is classified as Cluster A personality disorder.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 746.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient comes to the psychiatry OPD with complaints of repetitive thoughts that, he always feels his hands are dirty, though they are not. This gives him discomfort and hence he has to wash them again and again. This is a disorder of thought:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Possession

 

The patient is experiencing obsessive thoughts. Obsessions are repetitive, intrusive, and unwanted thoughts that cause significant anxiety or distress. The individual recognizes that the obsessions are a product of his or her own mind, but they feel as though they can't control the thoughts, hence they fall under the category of disorders of thought possession.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Flow: Refers to the rate and speed of thoughts. Examples of disorders of flow include flight of ideas or inhibition of thinking.

 

Option B. Form: Refers to the organization and structure of thought. Examples of disorders of form include tangentiality, circumstantiality, and word salad.

 

Option D. Content: Refers to what person is actually thinking about, such as delusions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Obsessions, as seen in obsessive-compulsive disorder, are considered disturbances of thought possession because while the individual recognizes the thoughts as their own, they feel as though they can't control them.

 

Reference: Fish’s Clinical Psychopathology, 4th edition, Page No 46.
